docs.lead_paragraph: So the big factual debate in the health summit was over whether insurance premiums would rise or fall under the Democratic plan. The answer is that they would fall -- but Republicans successfully threw up dust by pointing to the CBO conclusion that average payments to insurance companies would rise.
docs.abstract: Will reform seriously hurt people who would have had insurance coverage anyway? No.
docs.snippet: Will reform seriously hurt people who would have had insurance coverage anyway? No.

docs.lead_paragraph: Democrats and Republicans continued the political battle over health insurance reform in their weekly addresses in an extension of Thursday's 7-hour health care summit -- which was, if anything, divisive.

headline.main: The Saturday Word: Revisiting Health Care

docs.abstract: President Obama and Republicans kept up their differing views on health care in the dueling weekly addresses.

docs.lead_paragraph: Among the victims of Republican Senator Jim Bunning's move to stall a jobless benefits bill Thursday are small-business owners who hoped to take advantage of stimulus provisions to increase Small Business Administration lending.

headline.main: S.B.A. Stimulus Extension Lives, Then Dies, in Congress

docs.abstract: The bill appeared ready to sail through the Senate without a formal vote, until Jim Bunning, of Kentucky, objected.

docs.lead_paragraph: Better health does not seem to explain why so many young people forgo health insurance. Rather, income does, according to new survey data released by Gallup. One of the explanations for rising health care costs is that relatively healthy people are taking their chances and going without insurance.
docs.abstract: Gallup survey finds that one of explanations for rising health care costs is that relatively healthy young people are taking their chances and going without insurance (M)
